node.title: Has Queensland hit its COVID-19 vaccine ceiling?
node.alt: People in COVID face masks at the Brisbane Cultural Centre
node.description: As Queensland nears its 90 per cent vaccination target, expected to be reached this week, the rate of people getting the jab is slowing.
node.content:
["Queensland is expected to cross the 90 per cent vaccination rate threshold for those aged 16 and over\u00a0this week, but data shows the pace that people are getting vaccinated has slowed.", "About 91.55 per cent of that cohort have received at least one dose of vaccine, while 88.7 per cent are fully vaccinated.", "Queensland's Deputy Premier Steven Miles said all that was needed to achieve that goal was \"for all of those people who have had their first dose to get the second dose\".", "Mr Miles said there was an expectation that would happen \"now that people are getting back into the swing of things\"\u00a0after the festive season.", "\"I suspect some people whose three or four week mark fell over the Christmas New Year holiday period, they might have been away [or] they might not have wanted to get their second dose at that time,\" he said.", "According to infectious disease specialist Dr Paul Griffin, trends elsewhere have shown\u00a0vaccination rates \"slow towards the end,\" given people who have resisted getting\u00a0vaccinated and \"have resisted all the other efforts to try to get them vaccinated\".", "\"I think it has slowed in recent times, perhaps a little more than I expected,\" Dr Griffin said.", "", "
Authorities say there are several reasons behind Queensland's slowing vaccine rate.(AAP: Albert Perez)
", "He described the state's slowing vaccine take up as \"multi-factorial\".", "\"We did see a lot of sites closed down over the holiday period, so I think access declined to a degree,\" he said.", "\"Then of course, we saw the borders open, and Omicron really take off.\"", "
Mixed messaging\u00a0slows\u00a0vaccine uptake
", "Dr Griffin said\u00a0he also thought government messaging had been \"a little bit mixed\".", "\"Comments like, 'it's necessary to get', and 'we need to make sure people understand it is milder', that may have led some people to think that getting vaccinated didn't offer as many benefits as we know that it does.\"", "", "
The Univeristy of Queensland's Dr Paul Griffin\u00a0says mixed messaging has contributed to a slowing vaccine take up.(ABC News: Chris Gillette)
", "Dr Griffin said the risks of not vaccinating as many people as possible have already been seen in the number of hospitalisations in Queensland.", "He said unvaccinated people were an \"over-represented\" cohort of the people in hospital, and that there were parts of the population that \"don't understand the benefits\" of being vaccinated.", "\"I'm seeing these people every day,\" he said.", "\"Particularly large groups of pregnant women, for example, who are needing to be admitted to hospital because they didn't get vaccinated and now they're getting the infection and getting some of the most significant manifestations.\"", "
'An uphill battle'
", "Dr Griffin said vaccinating the remaining stragglers would be \"an uphill battle\", but\u00a0high vaccination numbers in other states showed there was a blueprint for achieving a higher rate.", "\"Those are extraordinary rates in New South Wales, Victoria and the ACT \u2026 rates we never thought we'd be able to achieve.\"", "New South Wales and Victoria both have 94 per cent of their over-16 population double dosed, while the ACT has a rate of 98.8 per cent.", "Dr Griffin said\u00a0the TGA's looming\u00a0decision about whether the protein vaccine Novavax would be available in Australia\u00a0could soon also have a positive effect on the rate.", "\"That will give an option to some people that have been reluctant to get the currently available vaccines,\" he said.", "
90pc vaccine target set to shake up travel rules
", "While many of the rules expected to change when the state reached a vaccination rate of 90 per cent for its over 16 population were relaxed over the weekend, there were still a few things that will alter when the state officially reaches the target.", "", "
Authorities say international travel is more likely to bring in new COVID-19 variants than domestic travel.(ABC News: Tim Swanston)
", "The biggest change will be for international arrivals, who will no longer need to quarantine provided they have been\u00a0vaccinated and have a negative COVID-19 test before they enter the country.", "Unvaccinated travellers entering the state from overseas will still have to undergo a period of quarantine, but exactly what that will be is yet to be laid out by the government.", "Deputy Premier Steven Miles yesterday flagged\u00a0\"there will continue to be a need for quarantine for some arrivals\".", "When announcing the early change of domestic border rules, Health Minister Yvette D'Ath said\u00a0international arrivals carry more risk than domestic travellers.", "\"Our international arrivals are the ones that will bring in new variants,\" she said.", "Restrictions on who can enter and access venues such as pubs, clubs and restaurants will remain.", "For the remaining 8.45 per cent of Queenslanders who are yet to receive a dose of vaccine, the Deputy Premier had a clear message.", "\"If you want to go to the pub, go and get vaccinated.\"", "", "
How to speak to your kids about their COVID-19 vaccination
"]
